title-group.article-title: Evaluation of the possibility of using surface free energy study to design protective fabrics

author-notes.corresp: Malgorzata Cieslak, Textile Research Institute, Department of Unconventional Technologies and Textiles, Brzezinska 5/15, 92-103 Lodz, Poland Email: cieslakm@iw.lodz.pl

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Contact angle measurements, using the dynamic contact angle and Washburn methods, were taken for 100% aramid and viscose fabrics, as well as for 50:50 aramid and viscose mixed fabrics of different structure. Based on the measurements of contact angles wetted with hexane, water and formamide, the fabric surface free energy was calculated by means of three (Owens–Wendt, Wu and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good) theoretical models. The aim of the study was to analyze the usefulness of the dynamic contact angle and Washburn methods for assessing surface properties of textile materials, using selected measurement liquids, and to relate the results to the further investigation of actual wetting and penetration of model fabrics designed to protect against hazardous or irritant liquids. It was found that both methods are useful for determining the fabric surface free energy values; the Washburn method is characterized by the high practical value in assessing surface properties of textile materials, regardless of their structure, whereas the dynamic contact angle method allows for more thorough observation of how the fabric structure of the same raw material composition exerts its effect on the wettability and surface free energy value.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Surface free energy (SFE) is one of the essential parameters of great importance in assessing properties of fibrogenic polymers.1 The SFE value is equal to the work needed to produce a new surface generated as a result of the partition of two phases in the equilibrium state in the reversible isothermal process.1 SFE plays an important role not only in technological processes (e.g., padding or coating), but also in shaping the utility and barrier qualities of textile products (e.g., vulnerability todirt, health care).2,3 Good knowledge of SFE facilitates the proper designing of textiles to be used for theproduction of specific/protective clothing (e.g., firefighters’ protective clothing), choice of appropriate finishing materials and the mode of their application. Appropriate designing of functional barrier materials, with special regard to their surface properties, is essential in view of the fact that they are used for protection against permeability (e.g., physiological fluids, liquids with irritating or flammable properties). The selection of suitable method/model, that allows for the specificity of textile materials (different properties of raw materials, structures, finishing), seems to be crucial for the next design stage.

There are a number of direct methods for calculating the SFE value of liquids,4,5 but to calculate SFE of solids indirect methods are required.1,4–7 Theoretical models, utilizing the results of contact angle measurements, are most frequently used to calculate SFE.1,4–10 A common method used for SFE determination is based on the goniometric technique, in which the image of the tested material set up, a bead of liquid and the measured angle produced by a drop of liquid with the solid surface, are recorded. This method has been used to calculate the SFE value of woolen fibers,11 and to assess the surface modification level of polyester (PET) fibers,12 polypropylene (PP) carpet fibers and polyamide (PA) carpets fibers.2,3 However, if the solid surface is not smooth, the liquid-solid interface gradually reaches the state of balance, which means that the measured contact angle between liquid and solid changes over time.13 In such a case, the Young’s equation7 alone is not enough to describe interactions on the boundary region of the liquid-solid interface, hence the coefficient of roughness must be involved. It is assumed that the effect of surface roughness on the contact angle is insignificant if the arithmetic mean deviation of the roughness profile is Ra <0.5 µm.1,13

Textile products, for example, fabrics, knitted fabrics and nonwovens, are characterized by the expanded surface structure, diversified in both the fiber type and production technique. The result of measurements taken with the use of goniometric techniques may significantly depend on the location of the drop on the sample. Therefore, studies have been carried out to work out the method for measuring the contact angle, appropriate for textile materials and based on both the modification of the goniometric technique itself, involving mathematical simulations14,15 and the application of other methods of contact angle measurements.15–20 Until now, the results of the studies on textile materials with the use of the Washburn (W) method have mostly been reported.19,20,22–24

The aim of this study was to analyze the differences in the contact angle values, measured with the use of two methods: the dynamic contact angle (DCA) method,16–18 and the Washburn method,19–21 as well as the differences in the values of SFE calculated with the use of three mathematical models (Owens–Wendt, Wu and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good).1–4,8,27 The major aim was to obtain basic information about the usefulness of the chosen experimental and calculation methods for designing functional barrier materials.

sec.title: The dynamic contact angle (DCA) method
sec.p:
This method involves the measurement of strength in scope of the solid-liquid interaction force. The material is subjected to immersion in and emergence from the standard liquid. Two variables are determined, advancing (θA) and receding (θR) angles (Figure 1). Figure 1.
The principle of the dynamic contact angle (DCA) method: (1) immersion and (2) emergence.25

The value of the DCA16 is calculated from the Wilhelmy equation (1): (1) where F is the wettability strength (mN); P is the wetted perimeter (m); γ1 is the surface tension of the standard liquid (mN/m), θ is the contact angle.

If the value of the wetted perimeter remains unknown, it can be determined by using the liquid of known surface tension γ1, which completely wets the surface under the study.18 Then, the contact angle θ equals to 0, and theequation (1) takes the form of F = γ1P (1a).

sec.title: The Washburn (W) method
sec.p:
This method involves the determination of the relationship between the mass of the liquid absorbed by the surface of porous material and time.19–25 The porous material sample, hanging on the balance hook, remains motionless and the vessel with the standard liquid is lifted until the sample contacts the liquid surface (Figure 2). At this moment the measurement of the absorbed liquid mass begins. Figure 2.
The principle of the Washburn (W) contact angle method.25
The contact angle is calculated on the basis of the above-mentioned relationship according to the modified Washburn equation (2): (2)

where m is the absorbed liquid mass (g); t is the time (s); C is the constant characteristic of the examined solid sample (cm5); ρ is the liquid density (g/cm3); γ is the liquid surface tension (mN/m); θ is the contact angle; and η is the liquid viscosity (mPa s).

The capillary velocity is obtained – this is mass2 versus time (m2/t) during the measurement. From the straight line of this curve the contact angle is calculated by the modified Washburn equation (2). The first adsorption experiment is performed with liquid that is known to have a contact angle of zero, i.e. hexane, andthe material constant C is determined on the basis of this measurement. The relationship (2) yields: (2a)
The experiment is then continued with other liquids. This method applies to Newtonian liquids only.26

sec.title: Surface free energy evaluation
sec.p: SFE of the materials under the study is calculated with the use of three models: Owens–Wendt,1,7 Wu1 and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good.1,8,27 These models are based on the calculation of the solid surface contact angle with standard liquids and the application of the Young’s equation (3),1,7,28,29 in which the influence of air on solid and liquid surfaces was not taken into account. (3) where γlv is the liquid surface tension, θ is the Young’s contact angle, γsv is the surface energy of the solid, γsl is the solid/liquid interface tension.

The development of the models has been based on Good and Grifalco’s1,27 theory developed by Fowkes. This theory includes two assumptions: first, that the total SFE (γs) is a sum of the independent energy components associated with intermolecular interactions: (4) where γsd, γsp, γsh, γsi, γsab are the dispersion, polar, hydrogen bonds, induction and acid-base components, respectively; and second, that the interaction at the boundary region of the solid-liquid interface occurs only between the same kind of intermolecular forces and strongly depends on both interacting surfaces.

In the Owens–Wendt1,7 model, SFE is calculated from the geometric mean of dispersion and polar interactions between the solid and liquid, according to equation (5). The calculation of γs is based on the values of the contact angle θ of two liquids which differ substantially in the surface tension component values: (5)
The Wu equation (6) is based on the same assumptions as those of the Owens–Wendt model, but it utilizes the harmonic mean to describe the intermolecular interactions: (6)

The van Oss–Chaudhury–Good1,8,27 model represented by equation (7) is based on the assumption that the forces associated with the acid-base components are the core forces of intermolecular interactions: (7) in addition to (7a) (7b) where γsAB is the acid-base associated component and γsLW is the distant-range component associated with dispersion, polar and induction interactions.
To calculate SFE with the use of the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model, at least three different standard liquids need to be applied, one of which is apolar and two are dipolar.8,27

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p: Three independent measurements of the contact angle were taken for each type of fabric and for each method. The SFE values were calculated for each measured contact angle. All measurements were carried out at the temperature of 20 ± 1°C and relative humidity 50 ± 2%.

sec.title: Fabrics
sec.p: The study comprised fabrics made of staple fiber yarn ofdiversified composition and structure. The characteristics of fabrics are given in Figure 3 and Table 1, whereas Table 2 presents the characteristics of study samples of these fabrics. Assuming that the density of viscose fibers is 1.53 g/cm3,30 and that of aramid fibers is 1.34 g/cm3,28 the density value of 1.43 g/cm3 was adopted for the mixture (50:50) of both fibers. Based on the fabric characteristics, its apparent density, ma, was calculated (8). In the Washburn method, in which the sample is additionally compressed, an apparent fiber density in a sample, maf, was determined (9). Based on the apparent fiber density the fiber content, Zf (10), and the volume of free spaces in a sample, Wf (11), were determined: (8) (9) (10) (11) where ma is apparent density (g/cm3), maf is apparent fiber density in the sample (g/cm3), ms is the mass per unit area (g/m2), b is the fabric thickness (cm), m is the sample mass (g), m = 10−4 ms S (g);
S is the sample area (cm2), SDCA = 2 cm2, SW = π r2 = 0.63585 cm2;
V is the sample volume (cm3); VDCA = SDCAb (cm3), VW* = 7.5 SWb (cm3);

d is the fiber density (g/cm3); Zf is the fiber content in a sample (%); Wf is the volume of free spaces in the fabric (%); * in compressed state as described in thesection below, ‘Preparation and examination of samples– the W method’. Figure 3.
Microscopic images of fabric samples A–E, *magnification. Table 1.

sec.title: Standard liquids
sec.p:
Three non-reactive liquids with different polarity and acid/base properties were used. These were: hexane (T.J. Baker, purity determination GC, 99.0%), water (distilled) and formamide (A.G. Fluka, purity determination GC, 99.5%) with physicochemical properties summarized in Table 3. The standard liquids were selected according to the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model requirements,1,8,27 i.e.: at least three liquids, one of them apolar and two dipolar. Therefore, hexane was chosen as the apolar liquid, while water and formamide were chosen as the dipolar ones. Table 3.
Physicochemical properties of standard liquids
Standard liquid Surface tension, γ [mN/m] Viscosity*), η [mPa s] Density, ρ [g/cm3]
γ γd γp γ+ γ−
Hexane 18.4 18.4 0 0 0 0.292 0.655
Watera) 72.8 21.8 51.0 25.5 25.5 0.891 0.996
Waterb) 72.8 21.8 51.0 34.2 19.0
Formamidea) 58.0 39.0 19.0 2.28 39.6 1.020 0.799
Formamideb) 58.0 39.0 19.0 3.10 29.1
*) at 20°C. Data according to: a) Lewis scale, b) Lee scale.35

sec.title: Instruments
sec.p: In the DCA and W methods, the contact angles were measured with the use of a Tensiometer KSV Sigma 701 F with the integrated software (KSV Instruments, Finland).

Microscopic images of fabrics were obtained by meansof a stereoscopic microscope OLYMPUS, type SZ 60 (Olympus, Japan), coupled with a digital camera (Panasonic, Japan), whereas an electronic scanning microscope VEGA 3 LMU (TESCAN, the Czech Republic) was used to obtain the images of fiber cross-sections.
The fabric images were taken in the passing light at constant lighting; the clearance surface was calculated using the Microstudio Software.

A hand punch press for textile materials (STAN 58, Poland) was used to cut out fabric samples. Two types of blades, rectangular (10 mm × 20 mm) for the DCA method and round (9 mm in diameter) for the W method, were applied.
A Vibro Viscometer SV 10 (KSV Instruments, Finland) was used to measure viscosity of the standard liquids at 20 ± 2°C.

sec.title: Fabric preparation: petroleum ether extraction
sec.p: To remove auxiliary agents and dirt, a three-fold washing of the fabrics was held in 50 mL of petroleum ether (CHEMPUR, pure p.a.), then they were dried in the air for 1 h, at 20°C.

sec.title: Preparation and examination of samples – the DCA method
sec.p:
The fabric samples (10 × 20 mm; the longer side along the warp) were investigated. Using the adhesive tape, the shorter side was attached to a metal holder (10 mm wide) and hung on the tensiometer balance (Figure 4). The weight of the sample (including the holder) was tared on the balance. Afterwards, the liquid surface was slowly brought to the sample. The fabric sample was immersed into a 2 mm depth and then emerged (Figure 1). The weight changes were recorded and the wetting strength was calculated using the KSV software. Figure 4.
Preparation of fabric samples for the dynamic contact angle (DCA) method: (a) frontal view; (b) rear view.

sec.title: Preparation and examination of samples – the W method
sec.p: Ten fabric discs were cut out as described in the section above, ‘Instruments’. They were mounted layer upon layer with the right side down in a syringe (2 mL). The original bottom of the syringe was replaced by a metal net made of wire 30 µm in diameter (the net mash density of 16,000/cm2). In the syringe piston, four openings were made to facilitate the release of air displaced from the fabric by the absorbed liquid.

The discs were compressed to assure the good contact of individual layers, so that the compressed layer was 7.5-fold thicker than the fabric itself. The filled syringe was hung on the balance hook of the tensiometer (Figure 2). The weight of the sample (including the holder) was tared on the balance. Afterwards, the liquid surface was slowly brought near the sample until it touched the bottom of the syringe, then the solid sample touched the testing liquid and the measurement process was started (t = 0 and m = 0). The weight gain was recorded as a function of time using the KSV Tensiometer integrated software. Based on the measurements, it was found that with such a compression of the fabric discs no instant changes in the slope of the Washburn curve could be observed during the wetting process of successive layers. The examples of these measurements for fabric C are presented in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Illustrative example of curves recorded in the Washburn (W) method when 10 discs of fabric C were compressed and free arrangement (marked with*).

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: Statistical analyses were carried out using the Microsoft Excel Software. Non-parametric Mann-Whitney U-test was used to determine the statistical significance established at the value of p < 0.05.31

sec.title: Contact angle measurement
sec.p: Fabrics A, B, and C were made of the same mixed yarn. They differed in the warp and weft thread density, type of weaves and surface, thickness and porosity. Insignificant differences in the weft thread density were found in fabrics B and C, but they were found significant as compared with fabric A. Fabric D, made of aramid yarn with the same linear density as that of the mixed fabrics, showed the structure parameters close to those of fabric B. Fabric E, with the plain weave, was made of viscose yarn of linear density lower than other yarns. It differed from the remaining fabrics in both the composition and structure. Fabrics B, C and D of twill weave were characterized by a structure substantially more tight than fabrics A and E of plain weave, which was evidenced among others by basic differences in the size of clearances (Table 1). The characteristics of the fabric samples analyzed with the DCA and W methods revealed significant differences in their volume (Table 2).

The values of the contact angles measured with the use of hexane by means of the DCA and W methods varied, despite the fact that both methods are based on the common assumption that hexane is regarded as the best wetting liquid. It was assumed that in the W method the value of hexane contact angle was equal to 0. In the DCA method, based on the aforesaid assumption, the wet perimeter (P) was determined, and the minimal value of the contact angle wetted with hexane was adopted as P because of angle hysteresis. In the W method, it was assumed that the contact angle wetted with hexane was equal to 0, and based on this assumption material constant (C) was derived from equation (2). The measurement of the contact angles for water and formamide were based on the C value determined for hexane.

In the W method, the contact angles determined with water showed higher values for all fabrics than in the DCA method, except for fabric D. This could be connected with the absence of hydrophilic viscose fibers in fabric D.
An inverse relationship was observed for the values of the formamide contact angles.

sec.title: Evaluation of surface free energy
sec.p: In fabric D, the SFE values were higher than those obtained by Liu et al.32 for aramid fibers (17.38 mJ/m2). In fabric E, compared with the value of 50.06 mJ/m2 reported in the literature for viscose fibers,33 the SFE values obtained by the DCA method, were higher for the Owens–Wendt and Wu’s calculation models and lower for the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model. On the other hand, those obtained by the W method were lower for the Owens–Wendt and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good models (Table 5).

The analysis of statistical variation of differences between the mean SFE values, based on the contact angles measured by the DCA and W methods, indicated that the use of the Owens–Wendt (a) and Wu (b) calculation models revealed statistically significant differences only for fabric E (Table 6), whereas the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good (c) model showed statistically significant differences for fabric B. The statistical analysis of the mean SFE values obtained according to models (b + c), which differ substantially in theoretical assumptions, showed that there were no statistically significant differences in the DCA method for fabrics A vs. B and B vs. C, and in the W method for fabrics A vs. B, B vs. C and A vs. C (Table 7). Table 6.
Analysis of statistical significance of differences between mean values of surface free energy (SFE) calculated with the use of the same method on the basis of contact angle values determined according to the dynamic contact angle (DCA) and Washburn (W) methods
Sample Method DCA vs method W
a vs a b vs b c vs c
A NS NS NS
B NS NS P < 0.05
C NS NS NS
D NS NS NS
E P < 0.05 P < 0.05 NS
a, Owens–Wendt; b, Wu; c, van Oss–Chaudhury–Good; NS, not significant.
Table 7.
Analysis of statistical significance of differences between mean values of surface free energy (SFE) calculated with the use of methods b and c on the basis of contact angle values determined according to the dynamic contact angle (DCA) and Washburn (W) methods
Sample Method DCA, N = 6 (b + c) Method W, N = 6 (b + c) Sample Method DCA vs method W, N = 6 (b + c)
A vs B NS NS A vs A NS
B vs C NS NS B vs B NS
A vs C P < 0.05 NS C vs C NS
D vs E P < 0.001 P < 0.001 D vs D NS
A vs D P < 0.001 P < 0.001 E vs E NS
A vs E P < 0.05 P < 0.01
b, Wu; c, van Oss–Chaudhury–Good; NS, not significant.

In the DCA method, the investigated sample was in a ‘free’ state and its immersion was compatible with the warp direction. In the W method, the sample composed of ten layers was compacted, and its immersion in the liquid was perpendicular to the weft-warp structure. Thus, the investigated structures of the same fabrics differed in both methods of the contact angle measurement (Table 2). Despite the methodological differences, the forms of the examined samples and disparate relationships, the water and formamide contact angle values in the DCA and W methods, and the mean SFE values, calculated from energy determined according to the Wu and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good models (b + c), did not show statistically significant differences in any of the fabrics used in the study (DCA vs. W, Table 7). It was revealed that the nearly 50:50 energy value, which is characteristic of the mean SFE value, calculated from the energy value for homogeneous fabrics D and E, was obtained for mixed fabrics A, B and C (Figure 6). Figure 6.
Comparison of SFE mean values of three mixed fabrics (A,B,C) with SFE mean values obtained from SFE values of homogeneous fabrics (D,E) for W and DCA contact angle measurement methods and a,b,c calculation models of SFE (I – the Lewis scale, II – the Lee scale).

The calculated SFE value may depend not only on the selected set of measurement liquids, but also on the assumed scales showing the interrelationship between the acid-base components of these liquids (Table 3).34–36

The comparison of the SFE values (Figure7), determined on the basis of the Lewis1,8,9,27–29,34 and Lee34,35 scales, shows significant differences between the mean SFE values, calculated in the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model and applying the DCA method (for homogeneous fabrics D and E and also for mixed fabrics A, B and C) when the contact angles were measured according to the W method. The results obtained for the same fabrics, using the Owens–Wendt and Wu models, are very similar, regardless of the scale used. Figure 7.
Comparison of surface free energy values for W and DCA contact angle measurement methods and a,b,c calculation models of SFE (I – the Lewis scale, II – the Lee scale).

Shalel-Levanon et al.9 calculated the maximum relative error (MRE) of the solids’ SFE value, determined according to the models of Owens–Wendt and van Oss–Chaudhury–Good, depending on the selection of the measurement liquids. In the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model, the minor relative error (below 0.1 for the measured contact angles <150°) was determined in the case when the liquids for calculations were applied according to the following option: i) apolar liquid, and two monopolar liquids, ii) liquid that has only the base component, and iii) liquid that has only the acid component. The same values of the error were obtained using the Owens–Wendt model, when one apolar liquid and one polar liquid were considered. However, when the SFE value was considered in the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model in the aforesaid option, the value of the error was determined entirely on the basis of the theoretical calculations, without supplying the examples of specific monopolar liquids. The mathematical calculations in the van Oss–Chaudhury–Good model and the option with one polar liquid and two dipolar liquids indicated that the 1° measurement error of the contact angle results in the significant MRE value of SFE components.9

Polyimide amide D and viscose E fabrics differ greatly in their SFE values, however, the SFE values of fabrics composed of a mixture of these fibers (A,B,C) approximate the SFE mean values of their components. The contact angle (DCA method) of the water-wetted viscose fabric is 2.5-fold smaller than that of polyimide amide fabric and two-fold smaller in formamide-wetted viscose fabrics. It is quite understandable since the viscose SFE value (about 56 mJ/m2) is very high and much closer to the SFE value of both liquids (water, 72.8 mJ/m2; and formamide, 58.0 mJ/m2) than to the SFE value (22 mJ/m2) of polyimide amide. The polar components of liquids and fiber polymers also play an important role. In the mixed fabrics, contact angles also show the values close to contact angle means of homogeneous fabrics, although no evident relationship could be observed. This may be influenced by the density of warp and the kind of weave/structure.

The W method yields evidently larger water contact angle for viscose fabric than the DCA method. This may be caused by an apparent higher density of the sample and swelling of the water-wetted fiber, which may reduce the rate of water absorption by the sample. These observations indicate that a simple mixing of two tested fibers in the yarn does not produce optimal results in the liquid-protecting fabrics made of different fibers, frequently characterized by opposite surface properties. Knowing well the SFE of fibers and the surface tension of the liquids (against which the fabric is supposed to protect), it seems to be possible to develop such an arrangement of individual fibers in the yarns and the fabric weaves, which will make it possible to obtain a maximal contact angle in the fabric and a minimal rate of liquid absorption, simultaneously, the decline of the utility properties will be avoided. This assumption needs to be confirmed by exploring the model fabrics designed to protect against solvents, acids and other liquids. At the same time, hygiene or fire and high temperature protection standards need to be met, which involves the combination of different raw textile materials.

In the further studies, current results of the SFE methodology research must also be taken into consideration for a better understanding of the wetting processes, especially in the case of such complex material as protective textiles.

sec.title: Conclusions
Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the Ministry of Science and Higher Education, Poland (Grant Nos: NN 508 379035, G 016/T02/2007)
